Chapter: Swine CAFOs and Water Quality in NC
Description: Concentrated Animal Feeding Operations (CAFOs) are facilities containing a large number of livestock housed in tight conditions. This project examined the impact of swine CAFOs on water quality in Eastern NC during flood conditions.

There are 2237 registered swine CAFOs in NC. There are many more that are not registered with the state. CAFOs use outdoor ponds or lagoons to store animal waste. This waste is sprayed onto nearby fields and can runoff into local waterways. When there is heavy rain such as in hurricane conditions, the lagoons can overflow and fecal mater can escape.
Hydrologic Unit Codes (HUCs) are a way to delineate watersheds and subwatersheds. This HUC has a 590 CAFOs, the highest number in the entire state.

In comparison, this HUC has only 8 CAFOs. Both of these HUCs are within the Cape Fear River Basin, but CAFOs are not evenly distributed throughout the state. Many of them are located in the floodplain of Eastern NC, an area vulnerable to flooding.

This is a time series of fecal coliform before, during and after Hurricane Florence. With more high quality water data available, analysis like this can illuminate trends in water quality related to swine CAFOs.

Swine CAFOs are an Environmental Justice concern that disproportionately affect Black and low income communities. Further reasearch and action is necessary to protect people's access to clean drinking water.
